title: 111_hr2424
content: The Act titled "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009" is referred to as the short title. It includes findings related to the Act. The Congress found that in August 2007, liquidity dried up in credit and securities markets, initially affecting financial firms with interests in mortgage-backed securities. This lack of credit access spread globally, leading to the Federal Reserve establishing a target range of 0 to 0.25 percent in December 2008. The Federal Reserve responded to the financial crisis by setting a target range of 0 to 0.25 percent for the Federal funds rate in December 2008, acknowledging the severity of the crisis and using its authority to address unusual circumstances multiple times. The Federal Reserve has responded to "unusual and exigent circumstances" by exercising its authority multiple times since the financial crisis began. This includes providing assistance to nonmember institutions and purchasing debt obligations. During the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve provided assistance to nonmember institutions and purchased debt obligations from government-sponsored enterprises for the first time since 1981. Additionally, joint programs were established with the Department of the Treasury to aid financial markets, including guaranteeing assets of Citigroup and Bank of America. Chairman Ben Bernanke emphasized transparency in his testimony on February 10, 2009. The Federal Reserve provided assistance to nonmember institutions during the financial crisis and purchased debt obligations from government-sponsored enterprises. Joint programs were established with the Department of the Treasury to aid financial markets, including guaranteeing assets of Citigroup and Bank of America. Chairman Ben Bernanke emphasized transparency in his testimony on February 10, 2009. SEC. 3. REVIEWS OF SPECIAL FEDERAL RESERVE CREDIT FACILITIES. Section 714 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Comptroller General to conduct reviews of credit facilities established by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or any Federal reserve bank. This includes onsite examinations when deemed necessary. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 allows the Board or any Federal reserve bank to establish credit facilities for approved functions, including acting as the lender of last resort and providing temporary assistance to private institutions. The credit facilities covered by this act include the Money Market Investor Funding Facility and the Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 covers various credit facilities including the Money Market Investor Funding Facility, Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility, Term Auction Facility, Primary Dealer Credit Facility, Commercial Paper Funding Facility, Term Securities Lending Facility, Maiden Lane, LLC, Maiden Lane II, LLC, and Maiden Lane III, LLC. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 includes various credit facilities such as the Term Securities Lending Facility, Maiden Lane, LLC, Maiden Lane II, LLC, Maiden Lane III, LLC, Revolving Credit Facility, Reciprocal currency arrangements with foreign central banks, Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program, and special purpose vehicles for credit facilities. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 includes the purchase of debt obligations from a Government Sponsored Enterprise and the use of special purpose vehicles for credit facilities. The authority for these activities will cease after a 5-year period, and a report on each review conducted must be submitted to Congress within 90 days. The report will detail the findings of the review. The Comptroller General must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of completing a review, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative or administrative action. SEC. 4. ACCESS TO RECORDS. Access to Records under Section 714(d)(1) of title 31, United States Code, is expanded to include any credit facility established by an agency. The Comptroller General is granted access to agency personnel, contractors, and representatives for record inspection and copying. Unauthorized access under Section 714(d)(2) is also addressed. The Comptroller General is authorized to request and retain copies of records deemed appropriate. Unauthorized access under Section 714(d)(2) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include copies of records and credit facilities established by an agency.
